title: Rendering Quarto document with project-specific Anaconda Python environment in RStudio/Posit
text:
Suppose you were trying to run a quarto document in Rstudio. In that case, it will run fine if your default Python version has the correct libraries installed. But what if you are working on a project where project-specific libraries are to be installed and used? And all to be set up in an Anaconda Python environment in RStudio?
It is possible. However, setting up a custom Anaconda environment and using that specific Python version is not apparent. You might have to spend some time to figure out from Stackoverflow and some GitHub issue queues.
I’ve figured it out after spending a couple of hours. I wanted to document this in case I need it later, or someone else might need it.
Here it is.

title: Rendering Quarto document with project-specific Anaconda Python environment in RStudio/Posit
text:
Steps at a glance

Create a Python environment using Anaconda distribution. I use this because it is easy to use
Install the necessary libraries in that environment
Create a Quarto project in RStudio
Set the project-specific Renviron

Set the Python interpreter for your project in Rstudio
Check if Quarto and Jupyter are properly connected to the Python version you want
Render

title: Rendering Quarto document with project-specific Anaconda Python environment in RStudio/Posit
text:
Setting up Anaconda
I will skip this section, assuming that you either have Anaconda installed or are managing your Python environment in other ways. If you need help with that, please search on YouTube; there are good videos on this topic.

title: Rendering Quarto document with project-specific Anaconda Python environment in RStudio/Posit
text:
Setting up RStudio
The first is to create a separate Rstudio project to house your code and documents. We’re using Python with the Jupyter engine to run the Quarto document.

title: Rendering Quarto document with project-specific Anaconda Python environment in RStudio/Posit
text:
Check your current Jupyter engine
From within Rstudio, use the Terminal tab (bottom left panel). It should open the terminal within Rstudio. On the CLI, type the following.
quarto check jupyter
This should produce an output like the following:
[✓] Checking Python 3 installation....OK
      Version: 3.8.13 (Conda)
      Path: /Users/enayetraheem/opt/anaconda3/envs/ibis3813/bin/python
      Jupyter: 4.10.0
      Kernels: python3

[✓] Checking Jupyter engine render....OK
Notice that it shows the current Python engine, which is /Users/enayetraheem/opt/anaconda3/envs/ibis3813. Also, we can see the Jupyter version here.
Where does Rstudio get this information from?
The short answer is: from the global .Renviron file. In the current Renviron, this is what I have.
QUARTO_PYTHON=/Users/enayetraheem/opt/anaconda3/envs/ibis3813/bin/python
If you want to use this Python environment, then you are good. It should run Python without issues. Also, ensure new libraries are installed in this environment for you to use in this notebook.

title: Rendering Quarto document with project-specific Anaconda Python environment in RStudio/Posit
text:
The problem
The problem occurs when you want to use a different environment! The one you see above is the global environment. RStudio will choose this unless you specify a project-specific .Renviron.
The solution seems easy.
Let’s take a look at the current setup.

There is no Python interpreter set for the current project. We can select one, but that won’t work.
Let’s set the Python interpreter to be the following:

Let’s restart RStudio. And check back, Quarto.
When you run quarto check jupyter, you will get the same response as before, not the Python you’ve set up with, as shown in the screenshot above.

title: Rendering Quarto document with project-specific Anaconda Python environment in RStudio/Posit
text:
The solution
The solution is to set project-specific .Renviron

usethis::edit_r_environ(scope = "project")

When you execute this, it will open up the editor, where you can put the following information.
QUARTO_PYTHON=/Users/enayetraheem/opt/anaconda3/envs/chasing-python/bin/python3.11

title: Rendering Quarto document with project-specific Anaconda Python environment in RStudio/Posit
text:
Restart
Make sure to restart your entire RStudio and then reopen the project. Then run in the terminal the
quarto check jupyter
This should render the following.

[✓] Checking Python 3 installation....OK
      Version: 3.11.5 (Conda)
      Path: /Users/enayetraheem/opt/anaconda3/envs/chasing-python/bin/python3.11
      Jupyter: 5.5.0
      Kernels: python3


[✓] Checking Jupyter engine render....OK

title: Rendering Quarto document with project-specific Anaconda Python environment in RStudio/Posit
text:
Summary
This article demonstrated the steps to set up a Python interpreter in a local RStudio project. We used the Anaconda Python package manager to create and manage the envs. Then we use usethis::edit_r_environ() library with scope="project" argument to edit the project-specific Python interpreter.

title: Causal Inference
text: One of the most repeated phrases in any introductory statistics class is the warning that “correlation is not causation.” This chapter presents new non-statistical language for creating, measuring, and evaluating causal stories and relationships using observational (i.e. non-experimental) data. It introduces the concept of causal directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) that allow us to formally encode our understanding of causal stories. With well-crafted DAGs, one can use a set of rules called do-calculus to make specific adjustments to statistical models and isolate or identify causal relationships between variables of interest. Edges (or arrows) transmit associations between nodes. Following the fundamental problem of causal inference, answering causal questions without an experiment appears impossible. The chapter explores different methods of making adjustments using synthetic data. Instead of throwing away potentially useful data, one can use other methods to create matches that are less discrete and more informative.

title: Who Cares About Crackdowns? Exploring the Role of Trust in Individual Philanthropy
text:
Abstract
The phenomenon of closing civic space has adversely impacted INGO funding. We argue that individual private donors can be important in sustaining the operations of INGOs working in repressive contexts. Individual donors do not use the same performance-based metrics as official aid donors. Rather, trust can be an important component of individual donor support for nonprofits working towards difficult goals. How does trust in charitable organizations influence individuals’ preferences to donate, especially when these groups face crackdown? Using a simulated market for philanthropic donations based on data from a nationally representative sample of individuals in the United States who regularly donate to charity, we find that trust in INGOs matters substantially in shaping donor preferences. Donor profiles with high levels of social trust are likely to donate to INGOs with friendly relationships with host governments. This support holds steady if INGOs face criticism or crackdown. In contrast, donor profiles with lower levels of social trust prefer to donate to organizations that do not face criticism or crackdown abroad. The global crackdown on NGOs may thus possibly sour NGOs’ least trusting individual donors. Our findings have practical implications for INGOs raising funds from individuals amid closing civic space.

title: Who Cares About Crackdowns? Exploring the Role of Trust in Individual Philanthropy
text:
Data and code
The project is reproducible with R code available at GitHub. Follow the instructions there to install all supporting files and R packages.
This project includes the following data files:

data/raw_data/final_data.rds: Original results from the Qualtrics survey. This is hosted at OSF because of its size. Running targets::tar_make(survey_results_file) will download the .rds file from OSF and place it in data/raw_data. The code for cleaning and processing this data is part of a separate project, “Why Donors Donate”.
data/derived_data/survey_results.csv: CSV version of the survey data.
data/derived_data/survey_results.yaml: YAML metadata describing the syntax of the survey data.
data/raw_data/posterior_draws/public_political_social_charity_demo.rds: Gamma (Γ) coefficients from our multilevel Bayesian model. This is hosted at OSF because of its size. Running targets::tar_make(gamma_draws_file) will download the .rds file from OSF and place it in data/raw_data/posterior_draws. The code for running this model is part of a separate project, “Why Donors Donate”.
data/raw_data/Market Simulator Version 01.xlsx: An interactive Excel version of the market simulator to help demonstrate the intuition behind all the moving parts of the simulation.

title: Welcome!
text:
I am a data scientist holding a Ph.D. in statistics and currently serving as a Principal Clinical Data Scientist at ICON, where I support the Data Science and Innovation group.
Over the past 8 years, my experience has covered diverse areas, including assisting healthcare providers with hospital and electronic health record (EHR) data, supporting payors with medical claims analytics, and collaborating with bio-pharma on Real-World Data (RWD) for Real-World Evidence (RWE) generation, and clinical trials data.
In terms of programming expertise, I have more than 20 years of experience in R and over 8 years with Python, both in on-premises and cloud computing environments. I am proficient in both languages and select the most suitable one depending on the specific problem.
Furthermore, I have a strong passion for teaching and sharing my knowledge with emerging data professionals. I am the founder and chief instructor at dataskool, an online learning platform dedicated to providing accessible data science and AI training for Bengali-speaking audiences.

title: Researching and finding internship opportunities in the U.S.
text:
Certainly! Focusing specifically on researching and finding internship opportunities in the United States for fresh undergraduates, here are detailed insights and actionable steps to guide you through this crucial phase:
Researching and Finding Internship Opportunities in the U.S.
Securing an internship in the United States is a competitive process that requires strategic research and a proactive approach. Here’s how you can effectively search and apply for internship opportunities:
1. Start with a Clear Objective


Define Your Goals: Know what you want to gain from your internship experience. Are you looking for specific skills, industry exposure, or a potential pathway to employment? This clarity will guide your search.

Identify Your Field of Interest: Narrow down the industries and roles that interest you. This focus will make your search more manageable and targeted.
2. Research Companies


Create a List of Target Companies: Identify companies that align with your career goals and have a history of offering internships. Don’t limit yourself to large corporations; small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and startups can also offer valuable experiences.

Company Websites: Regularly check the careers section of your target companies’ websites for internship listings. Many companies prefer to post opportunities on their own platforms before advertising elsewhere.
3. Utilize Online Platforms and Job Boards


Internship-Specific Platforms: Websites like Internships.com, WayUp, and Chegg Internships are dedicated to internship listings and can be filtered by location, industry, and role.

General Job Boards: LinkedIn, Indeed, Glassdoor, and Monster also list internships. Use filters to narrow down your search to entry-level and internship positions.

Industry-Specific Websites: Depending on your field, look for niche job boards that specialize in your industry. These can often list internships not found on larger platforms.
4. Leverage University Resources


Career Services: Your university’s career services office can connect you with internship opportunities and alumni working in your field of interest. They may also have partnerships with companies seeking interns.

Job Fairs and Networking Events: Attend university and external career fairs, as well as industry networking events. These can be excellent opportunities to meet employers and learn about internships firsthand.
5. Network Effectively


Informational Interviews: Reach out to professionals in your field for informational interviews. This is a way to learn about the industry and potentially uncover unadvertised internship opportunities.

Social Media and Professional Networks: Use LinkedIn to connect with industry professionals and join relevant groups. Engaging with content and participating in discussions can increase your visibility and open up opportunities.

Alumni Networks: Connect with alumni from your university who are working in the U.S. They can offer valuable advice and might know of internship opportunities in their companies.
6. Attend Industry Conferences and Workshops


Conferences and Seminars: These events are excellent for learning current industry trends and networking with professionals. Some conferences offer student rates or volunteer opportunities which can provide free or reduced-cost access.

Workshops and Online Webinars: Participate in workshops and webinars related to your field of interest. These can be platforms for learning and networking.
7. Monitor Specialized Forums and Newsletters


Professional Forums: Join forums and online communities specific to your industry. Members often share job openings and internship opportunities.

Subscribe to Newsletters: Many industry-specific websites and professional organizations send out newsletters that include job and internship listings.
8. Apply Strategically


Customize Your Application: Tailor your resume, cover letter, and application materials to each internship opportunity. Highlight relevant skills, experiences, and coursework.

Prepare for the Process: Be ready for a competitive application process. This includes preparing for interviews, potentially taking part in assessment days, and being proactive in follow-ups.
9. Stay Organized


Track Your Applications: Keep a spreadsheet or use job search apps to track the internships you’ve applied for, including application dates, follow-up actions, and responses.
10. Be Persistent and Flexible


Persistence is Key: The search for an internship can be challenging and may require time and persistence. Don’t get discouraged by rejections.

Flexibility: Be open to a wide range of opportunities, including those that may not be your first choice but offer valuable experience and growth.

By focusing your efforts on thorough research and strategic application, you can significantly improve your chances of securing an internship in the U.S. Remember, the process is highly competitive, and success often comes to those who are well-prepared, proactive, and persistent in their search.

## Summary

This article demonstrated the steps to set up a Python interpreter in a local RStudio project. We used the Anaconda Python package manager to create and manage the envs. Then we use `usethis::edit_r_environ()` library with `scope="project"` argument to edit the project-specific Python interpreter.
